sect2.title: Overview
sect2.para: Zend_Uri is a component that aids in manipulating and validating Uniform Resource Identifiers (URIs). Zend_Uri exists primarily to service other components, such as Zend_Http_Client, but is also useful as a standalone utility.

URIs always begin with a scheme, followed by a colon. The construction of the many different schemes varies significantly. The Zend_Uri class provides a factory that returns a subclass of itself which specializes in each scheme. The subclass will be named Zend_Uri_<scheme>, where <scheme> is the scheme, lowercased with the first letter capitalized. An exception to this rule is HTTPS, which is also handled by Zend_Uri_Http.

sect2.title: Creating a New URI
sect2.para: Zend_Uri will build a new URI from scratch if only a scheme is passed to Zend_Uri::factory().

example.title: Creating a New URI with Zend_Uri::factory()

sect2.para:
To create a new URI from scratch, pass only the scheme to Zend_Uri::factory()
At the time of writing, Zend_Uri only provides built-in support for the HTTP and HTTPS schemes.. If an unsupported scheme is passed and no scheme-specific class is specified, a Zend_Uri_Exception will be thrown.
If the scheme or URI passed is supported, Zend_Uri::factory() will return a subclass of itself that specializes in the scheme to be created.

sect3.title: Creating a New Custom-Class URI
sect3.para: Starting from Zend Framework 1.10.5, you can specify a custom class to be used when creating the Zend_Uri instance, as a second parameter to the Zend_Uri::factory() method. This enables you to subclass Zend_Uri and create your own custom URI classes, and instantiate new URI objects based on your own custom classes.

The 2nd parameter passed to Zend_Uri::factory() must be a string with the name of a class extending Zend_Uri. The class must either be alredy-loaded, or loadable using Zend_Loader::loadClass() - that is, it must follow the Zend Framework class and file naming conventions, and must be in your include_path.

example.title: Creating a URI using a custom class

sect2.title: Manipulating an Existing URI
sect2.para: To manipulate an existing URI, pass the entire URI to Zend_Uri::factory().

example.title: Manipulating an Existing URI with Zend_Uri::factory()

sect2.para: The URI will be parsed and validated. If it is found to be invalid, a Zend_Uri_Exception will be thrown immediately. Otherwise, Zend_Uri::factory() will return a subclass of itself that specializes in the scheme to be manipulated.

sect2.title: URI Validation
sect2.para: The Zend_Uri::check() method can only be used if validation of an existing URI is needed.

example.title: URI Validation with Zend_Uri::check()

sect2.para: Zend_Uri::check() returns a boolean, which is more convenient than using Zend_Uri::factory() and catching the exception.

sect3.title: Allowing "Unwise" characters in URIs
sect3.para: By default, Zend_Uri will not accept the following characters: "{", "}", "|", "\", "^", "`". These characters are defined by the RFC as "unwise" and invalid; however, many implementations do accept these characters as valid.
Zend_Uri can be set to accept these "unwise" characters by setting the 'allow_unwise' option to boolean TRUE using Zend_Uri::setConfig():

example.title: Allowing special characters in URIs

note.para: Zend_Uri::setConfig() sets configuration options globally. It is recommended to reset the 'allow_unwise' option to 'FALSE', like in the example above, unless you are certain you want to always allow unwise characters globally.

sect2.title: Common Instance Methods
sect2.para: Every instance of a Zend_Uri subclass (e.g. Zend_Uri_Http) has several instance methods that are useful for working with any kind of URI.

sect3.title: Getting the Scheme of the URI
sect3.para: The scheme of the URI is the part of the URI that precedes the colon. For example, the scheme of http://www.zend.com is 'http'.

example.title: Getting the Scheme from a Zend_Uri_* Object

sect3.para: The getScheme() instance method returns only the scheme part of the URI object.

sect3.title: Getting the Entire URI

example.title: Getting the Entire URI from a Zend_Uri_* Object

sect3.para: The getUri() method returns the string representation of the entire URI.

sect3.title: Validating the URI
sect3.para: Zend_Uri::factory() will always validate any URI passed to it and will not instantiate a new Zend_Uri subclass if the given URI is found to be invalid. However, after the Zend_Uri subclass is instantiated for a new URI or an existing valid one, it is possible that the URI can later become invalid after it is manipulated.
The valid() instance method provides a means to check that the URI object is still valid.
